raw_text:
Strachan turns down Pompey
 
 Former Southampton manager Gordon Strachan has rejected the chance to become Portsmouth's new boss.
 
 The Scot was Pompey chairman Milan Mandaric's first choice to replace Harry Redknapp, who left Fratton Park for rivals Saints earlier in December. "I think it's a fantastic job for anybody apart from somebody who has just been the Southampton manager," Strachan told the BBC. Club director Terry Brady held initial talks with Strachan on Saturday. The former Scotland international added that joining Southampton's local rivals would not be a wise move. "It's got everything going for it but I've got too many memories of the other side and I don't want to sour those memories," he said. "Everything's right - it's 10 minutes away, there are good players there, a good set-up, a good atmosphere at the ground. "There's lots to do but it's not right for somebody who has just been the Southampton manager." Since Redknapp's departure, executive director Velimir Zajec and coach Joe Jordan have overseen first-team affairs.
 
 The duo had gone five matches unbeaten until Sunday's 1-0 defeat at home to champions Arsenal, but the club are still in a respectable 12th place in the Premiership table. Strachan left St Mary's in February, after earlier announcing his intention to take a break from the game at the end of the 2003-04 season. His previous managerial experience came at Coventry, whom he led for five years from 1996 to 2001.
llama3.2:1b: Gordon Strachan was offered Pompey's manager position and declined, citing concerns about his association with Southampton.
llama3.2:3b: Gordon Strachan has rejected the chance to become Portsmouth's new manager, citing his recent departure from Southampton as a reason. He believes joining Saints' local rivals would "sour" memories of his time at Pompey. The former Scotland international had held initial talks with club directors before making his decision.
gemma2:2b: Gordon Strachan declined the opportunity to become Portsmouth's new manager. He believes joining a rival club would be detrimental and he has too many strong memories of his time at Southampton. Despite the potential job benefits, Strachan prioritized a break from the game after leaving Southampton earlier this year.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Gordon Strachan has rejected the chance to become Portsmouth's new boss. He was originally chosen by Pompey chairman Milan Mandaric as a replacement for Harry Redknapp, who left Southampton earlier in December. However, he decided not to accept this offer. The club is currently in 12th place in the Premiership table after losing their previous unbeaten five-match run at home to Arsenal on Sunday.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Former Southampton manager Gordon Strachan has turned down Portsmouth's job as the club prepares for a return to the Premier League following Harry Redknapp's departure. Strachan believes it would be "souring" memories of his time at St Mary's, despite the benefits of being close to home and with a good set-up.
qwen2.5:3b: Former Southampton manager Gordon Strachan turned down Portsmouth's offer to become their new boss after Harry Redknapp left the club. Strachan considered it a great opportunity but declined due to his memories of his time at Southampton and the team's proximity, which he found too close for comfort. The club is still in 12th place in the Premiership despite recent setbacks under interim management. Prior to this offer, Strachan had managed Coventry City from 1996 to 2001.

smollm:1.7b: Strachan turned down Pompey as former Southampton manager.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to help this user by summarizing their text. Let's read through it carefully.

The first sentence is about Gordon Strachan rejecting Pompey as manager for Portsmouth. He was Pompey chairman and the first choice after Harry Redknapp left for Saints earlier in December. He told BBC that it's a fantastic job except if someone just came into Southampton. Terry Brady met him, but he mentioned joining rivals might not be smart. He thinks everything is right but mentions too many memories from the other side.

Then, there's information on Velimir Zajec and Joe Jordan leading first-team matters after Redknapp left. They had five unbeaten games against Arsenal. The club was in 12th place in the Premiership.

Finally, Strachan left St Mary's in February after his break at the end of 2003-04. He led Coventry from 1996 to 2001.

I need to extract key points: Strachan's decision, the rival club, management shift, team performance. I should keep it concise without explanations or formatting.
</think>

Gordon Strachan has rejected Pompey as manager for Portsmouth and will join Southampton's local rivals. He suggested joining a rival could sour memories from Pompey. The club is in 12th place in the Premiership with five unbeaten matches against Arsenal, facing promotion challenges due to his previous managerial career at Coventry (1996-2001).
tinyllama:1.1b: Former Southampton boss Gordon Strachan has turned down the opportunity to become Portsmouth's new head coach, citing reasons related to his previous experience as Pompey chairman and his desire to avoid playing on the local rival's turf. Despite being offered the job by Terry Bradby, Strachan explained that he wants to continue his work at Coventry, where he led the Sky Blues for five years from 1996 to 2001.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Former Southampton manager Gordon Strachan has rejected the chance to become Portsmouth's new boss, opting instead to take a break from professional football. The Scot was Pompey chairman Milan Mandaric's first choice to replace Harry Redknapp at Fratton Park, but felt it wasn’t the right time for him to return to the game after his tenure with Southampton. Strachan, who has been linked with various high-profile positions in English football, made it clear that he is not interested in becoming the local rivals of his former club, and stated that joining Pompey's local rivals would not be a wise move. The decision to turn down this opportunity highlights the importance of finding the right fit for both the club and the manager, ensuring a successful transition for both parties involved.
phi:2.7b: Gordon Strachan, former Southampton manager turned down the chance to become Portsmouth's new boss. He believes joining Southampton'S local rivals would not be a wise move due to his memories of the other side and the team's recent poor performance. Executive director Velimir Zajec and coach Joe Jordan have been managing first-team affairs since Redknapp's departure, with Strachan taking a break from the game at the end of the 2003-04 season.
orca-mini:3b: Former Southampton manager Gordon Strachan rejected the chance to become Portsmouth's new boss.
hermes3:3b: Gordon Strachan turned down Portsmouth offer as former Southampton manager.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Gordon Strachan declined Portsmouth's offer to become their new manager, citing his recent tenure as Southampton manager and the numerous memories associated with that club. He believed joining Pompermouth would sour those experiences. Strachan was Pompey chairman Milan Mandaric's preferred candidate to succeed Harry Redknapp, who had recently departed for Southampton. Prior to this role, Strachan managed Coventry City from 1996 to 2001. Portsmouth, under Zajec and Jordan, had recently maintained a five-match unbeaten streak but lost their previous match against Arsenal. Despite the team's 12th-place standing in the Premiership table, Strachan deemed it inappropriate to take on another managerial position so soon after leaving Southampton.
